abstract: Three new Kindle e-book readers from Amazon fall short of full-featured tablets, but they have much to offer at comparatively low prices.
snippet: Three new Kindle e-book readers from Amazon fall short of full-featured tablets, but they have much to offer at comparatively low prices.
lead_paragraph: If you think that the pace of technological progress is already too fast, you’d better not look at e-book readers. You’ll get whiplash.

headline.main: Fire Aside, Other Kindles Also Shine
headline.print_headline: Fire Aside, Other Kindles Also Shine

abstract: Kindle Fire tablets ship today, Chelsea Clinton becomes a correspondent for NBC News, a new magazine will cover only reality stars and other media news.
snippet: Kindle Fire tablets ship today, Chelsea Clinton becomes a correspondent for NBC News, a new magazine will cover only reality stars and other media news.
lead_paragraph: Steven Levy of Wired magazine profiles Jeff Bezos as Amazon ships its first Kindle Fire tablets today. The piece sets up Amazon vs. Apple. “Apple is fundamentally a hardware company — 91 percent of its revenue comes from sales of its coveted machines, compared to just 6 percent from iTunes,” he writes. “Amazon, on the other hand, is a content-focused company — almost half of its revenue comes from sales of media like books, music, TV shows, and movies — and the fire-sale-priced Fire is designed to be primarily a passport to the large amount of that content that’s available digitally.” [Wired]

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web looking for the most interesting, insightful and just plain odd news that might otherwise go unnoticed and unremarked. Today brings Roger McNamee on saving the Internet, freezing Amazon warehouse workers and Angry Birds in space. The complete Scuttlebot feed is in the right-hand column.
